turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Then you --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that would be just the same kind of an occurring as check-off --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) an occurring.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and there was nothing like that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are there cases -- are there cases in which a company union, concededly a company union was operating in the plant, who is in the plant?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Oh, yes, I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) was taken by the employer to enforce obedience to that arrangement with this company union.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think that there are, Your Honor, and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I meant, just like this.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think it would be.
The cases that Mr. Dunau refers to, however, are cases in which nothing like that was done.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you have one in your brief where that has been done with reference to a company union as to the statute of limitations, would you call my attention to them so I can see them?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I do not recall that I have one in my brief, Your Honor.
I would be glad to locate one and submit it to the Court after --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not challenging.
I -- I simply want to see it.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you may refuse.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Surely.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, why does the -- in the memorandum in which you submit that, would you make your observations on the cases to which Mr. Dunau refers?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The company-dominated union.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I will.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you do agree that you have to have what -- in order to have an occurring, an intervention by the employer of some sort or other and not merely that the subsistence is something that began prior to the six months?
Do you agree with that or don't you?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, I would say that the latter situation would make a much harder case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you decide to be wholly before you at this time?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think our case, though, is the -- is the case where the -- well, there is something occurring here.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You still have to know the facts in order to obtain what you say is a recurring act to the enforcement of the check-off and you -- you still have to go back in order to taint that within the period of limitation by the original vice that inhered in this contract.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: There is no question that you do, Your Honor, but that in itself, we submit, is -- is not enough to run a file of 10 (b) because we are not predicating any liability based upon those past acts.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Without any liability at all.
Independently of that, you don't have a case.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: But, Your Honor, you don't have a case in a number of other situations in which the Court of Appeals have -- has sustained the Board's position.
For example, I give you the situation in -- in the Paramount Cap case in the Eighth Circuit where an employee is discharged within the limitations period.
The employer says he's discharged for cause.
Now, you look at the employer's reasons and it doesn't seem to be caused but you'd have no evidence of anti-union motivation at all occurring within the six-month period.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But that's a wholly different situation because there, the charge is that he was discriminatorily discharged.
In order to give color to the character of this discharge, whether it was -- was discriminatory or not, you can then go back and to hear evidence to show what the nature of it was.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Here, Your Honor, the violation, as found by the Board, is maintaining a union security provision that did not comply with Section 8 (a) (3) of the Act.
There is no violation predicated on the execution of the original contract and the dues reimbursement provision excludes that period.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What you're saying is, if I understand you, that when an employer compels a union -- tells his employees to -- to give up the check-off or -- check-off to put into the security fund, etcetera, that's -- that's a neutral act and what you're doing is to illuminate what that means as to -- for what purposes and what's the meaning of that -- of that conduct.
Is that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore, when it comes to finding out what an ambiguous or a neutral act is, you can resort to evidence which, in and of itself, would not furnish a cause of action.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you have any case here if you didn't have that particular bridge of illumination signing on facts?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: In this particular case, probably not.
However --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose a man --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- suppose a man gives a note and it's gone.
It's bad.
He doesn't sue on it, he's barred by the statute of limitation statute.
In the meantime, the man gives another note.
Can they go back to the first transaction to see what the second note ordinarily and plead to the statute of limitations?
I suppose this is an ordinary statute of limitations.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about it?
Could you prove that it was bad by going back to the first note ordinarily?
I don't know.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think you could, Your Honor.
I think that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would that be because the first note was bad or because the second note was bad?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Because the second note was bad.
You're predicating liability on the second note.
You're not predicating -- it's like a continuing tort, in -- in a sense, in the example that Mr. Justice Whittaker gave.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) one time, the situation is (Inaudible) a cause of action is barred by limitations but it is set up defensively in offset of an affirmative cause of action.
Is it not generally the law that this action, this -- is set up, no barred, may be proved, in diminution or offsets of the affirmative cause of action?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I believe that it is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let's go back to my first case.
The notes there are barred the statute of limitations.
Would that be a good defense to it, that it's barred by the statute of limitations?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: The original note?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The original note, like you had here.
They had a good defense to you if you tried to do anything on this original execution of this contract, didn't they?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think so, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, does it -- does the first one get worse because the -- the few notes given are the same thing?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I -- I think it is.
I don't think that when you continue to do something affirmatively here, you're in the situation which is contemplated by the notion that you ought to have reposed.
Yet, you'd --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When you do something --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: -- understand --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- when you do something, you do something.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you understand to be the purpose of the repose?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: The purpose of the repose is to bar a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You look at -- you look at the Act instead of what you're looking at what something somebody's done in the way they reply, instead of looking it at law.
I may see it one way, at another way, the other.
Suppose, here, the -- the man here, you didn't have this second thing at all.

Suppose they hadn't done anything, would you say that you could keep them all the way up to the violation of the law through the years even though the Congress has said that in six years -- six months, it should be stopped?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, if --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What is the purpose of that?
What is the objection behind that?
It's reposed, isn't it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: It is reposed when you have stopped the conduct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, but if --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Had there been a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You have a contract, you have a system of making contracts and it's desirable at some time, they'd be at rest so that the public people will know whether they have a good contract or not.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you would just simply extend it like they've tried to do in conspiracy cases, wouldn't it, by the same method and technique?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, when you're enforcing a -- a union security clause each month, as you -- as you did here, you don't have a dispute that dies down.
As the court below observed, the dispute here involved is not the kind which varies easily but rankles at least once a month.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, how much did it rankle those six months or that year?
How many rankles did the Board hear about?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Were there any rankles at all?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, we got the -- we got the charge which initiated --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, we got the first charge, Your Honor, within 10 months of the execution of the contract which we --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How about that?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: --- which, we submit, is not unduly long in these matters because you must remember that the company here was building up its workforce.
You had new employees being added over this period.
It takes a while for the employees to find out what's going on and to build off enough support to want to do something about it.
And I'll -- I'll elaborate on that when I come back.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll recess.
